You may say I'm ignorant, or stupid, or insane - but I really didn't like this book. At all. I couldn't get into it, I couldn't decipher what was going on half the time, and if it weren't for the fact that I actually knew parts of the story, I wouldn't have been able to keep up, because it's a classic and almost everyone has heard of the story in one way or another.The writing style was so bland and tiresome. There was no pause, no break, just constant rambling. So much so, that I probably missed a lot of poignant or important moments because I would skim through huge chunks of it wondering what was happening or where it was going to take me.I know it's a classic, one that is loved by many, but it just wasn't for me. The way it was written, the way it was told, I just couldn't connect or get engrossed in the horror that was being described. I appreciate the message behind the book, of course, I did a lot of research to understand what I had read better, but if it weren't for all that research, I wouldn't have been able to appreciate the book. So in all honesty, I couldn't give it more than a star, based on the book as a standalone.Sorry. Not for me.

One of my favorite books. For me the other reviews missed the real point of the book. Plainly, as the title says it is about the Heart Of Darkness within mankind not about africans or colonialism which are just sets for the deep story. Time and again this heart of darkness is made clear. When Marlow gets the job with the company he has to have his head measured by the company physician before leaving on his assignment. Asking what this is all about the physician replies that the company keeps records of how employees are changed after completing there assignment - a foreboding of the horror that he will discover about mankind. I find it wonderful how Conrad describes how the company treats the machinery and their employees in the same manner. The employees and machinery are both abandoned to rot in the jungle when their useful life is reached. A most telling scene is evoked when Marlow notices a group of wealthy European enter the company jungle camp. He notes that they have none of the talents or motives of true explorers and are only motivated by greed and personal gain. After they slip out of camp on donkeys and are never heard of again, he wonders what happened to the better animals - the donkeys. This exposee of the unvarnished dark side of human nature continues to be exposed as the story proceeds all the way to Kurtz.

summary:
In a novella which remains highly controversial to this day, Conrad explores the relations between Africa and Europe. On the surface, this is a horrifying tale of colonial exploitation. The narrator, Marlowe journeys on business deep into the heart of Africa. But there he encounters Kurtz, an idealist apparently crazed and depraved by his power over the natives, and the meeting prompts Marlowe to reflect on the darkness at the heart of all men. This short but complex and often ambiguous story, which has been the basis of several films and plays, continues to provoke interpretation and discussion.

Heart of Darkness grew out of a journey Joseph Conrad took up the Congo River; the verisimilitude that the great novelist thereby brought to his most famous tale everywhere enhances its dense and shattering power.

Apparently a sailor’s yarn, it is in fact a grim parody of the adventure story, in which the narrator, Marlow, travels deep into the heart of the Congo where he encounters the crazed idealist Kurtz and discovers that the relative values of the civilized and the primitive are not what they seem. Heart of Darkness is a model of economic storytelling, an indictment of the inner and outer turmoil caused by the European imperial misadventure, and a piercing account of the fragility of the human soul.
